ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:0.3_0: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:0.4_0: 10. The training rule on schism in the Sangha
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.2_0: At that time Devadatta went to see Kokālika, Kaṭamodakatissaka, Khaṇḍadeviyā-putta, and Samuddadatta.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.3_0: “Come, let’s create a schism in the Sangha of the ascetic Gotama, a break in transmission.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.5_0: “The ascetic Gotama is powerful and mighty.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.7_0: “Well, let’s go to the ascetic Gotama and request five things:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.8_0: ‘Sir, in many ways the Buddha praises fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things, and being energetic.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.9_0: And there are five things that lead to fewness of wishes, contentment, self-effacement, seclusion, and arousing energy.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.11_0: If the monks stayed in the wilderness for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.12_0: and whoever stays near an inhabited area would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.13_0: If they ate only almsfood for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.14_0: and whoever accepts an invitational meal would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.15_0: If they were rag-robe wearers for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.16_0: and whoever accepts a robe from a householder would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.17_0: If they live at the foot of a tree for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.18_0: and whoever takes shelter would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.19_0: If they didn’t eat fish or meat for life,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.20_0: and whoever does would commit an offense.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.21_0: The ascetic Gotama won’t allow this.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.22_0: We’ll then be able to win people over with these five points.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.23_0: Kokālika said, “It might be possible to create a schism in the Sangha with these five points,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.24_0: for people have confidence in austerity.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.1_0: Devadatta and his followers then went to the Buddha,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.2_0: and told him what had happened,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.3_0: “Sir, in many ways the Buddha praises fewness of wishes, contentment, erasing of defilements, ascetic practices, being inspiring, reduction in things,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.5_0: And there are five things that lead to just that.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.7_0: It would be good, Sir, if the monks stayed in the wilderness for life, and
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.8_0: and whoever stays near an inhabited area would commit an offense;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.9_0: If they didn’t eat fish or meat for life, and whoever accepts a fish, saying, “They would commit an offense;”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.11_0: Those who wish may stay in the wilderness, and those who wish may live near inhabited areas.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.12_0: Those who wish may eat only almsfood, and those who wish may accept invitational meals.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.13_0: Those who wish may be rag-robe wearers, and those who wish may accept robes from householders.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.14_0: I have allowed a resting place at the foot of a tree for eight months of the year, as well as fish and meat which are pure in three respects:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.15_0: one hasn’t seen, heard, or suspected that the animal was specifically killed to feed a monastic.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.2.17_0: “The Buddha doesn’t allow the five points,” and he was glad and elated. He got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left with his followers.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.1_0: The foolish people with little faith and confidence said,

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.9_0: After rebuking Devadatta in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Devadatta:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.10_0: He said, “Is it true, Devadatta, that you’re pursuing schism in the Sangha, a break in transmission?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.13_0: “... Foolish man, how can you pursue schism in the Sangha?

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.15_0: the Buddha said, “And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.16.1_0: ‘If a monk pursues schism in a united Sangha or persists in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism, the monks should correct him,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.17_0: “Venerable, don’t pursue schism in the united Sangha or persist in taking up a legal issue conducive to schism.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.18_0: Stay with the Sangha, for a united Sangha—in concord, in harmony, having a joint recitation—is at ease.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.19_0: If that monk continues as before, the monks should press him up to three times to make him give up that view.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.20_0: If he then gives it up, all is well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.3.21_0: If he does not stop, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”
